objects.name: NCSC
objects.description: The UK National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) is the primary author and publisher of this report, providing analysis and detection guidance for Cyclops Blink.

objects.name: cyclops blink
objects.description: Cyclops Blink is a malicious Linux ELF executable, compiled for the 32-bit PowerPC (big-endian) architecture. It is a modular malware framework targeting Small Office/Home Office (SOHO) network devices, notably WatchGuard Firebox. Cyclops Blink maintains persistence throughout legitimate device firmware updates, implements a modular framework with a core component and additional modules, and uses custom C2 communication under TLS with individually encrypted messages. Its modules provide file upload/download, system information discovery, and malware update capabilities. The malware is capable of masquerading as a Linux kernel thread, modifying firewall rules, and maintaining persistence by patching firmware images.

objects.name: FBI
objects.description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) contributed to the acquisition of Cyclops Blink samples from WatchGuard Firebox devices for analysis.

objects.name: CISA
objects.description: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) is referenced as a collaborating organization in the analysis of Cyclops Blink.

objects.name: NSA
objects.description: The National Security Agency (NSA) is referenced as a collaborating organization in the analysis of Cyclops Blink.

objects.name: WatchGuard
objects.description: WatchGuard is the vendor of Firebox and other SOHO network devices targeted by Cyclops Blink. Their firmware update process is exploited by the malware for persistence.

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_notable_strings
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
rule CyclopsBlink_notable_strings
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "Detects notable strings identified within the
Cyclops Blink executable"
        date = "2022-02-23"
        hash1 = "3adf9a59743bc5d8399f67cab5eb2daf28b9b863"
        hash2 = "c59bc17659daca1b1ce65b6af077f86a648ad8a8"

    strings:
        // Process names masqueraded by implant
        $proc_name1 = "[kworker/0:1]"
        $proc_name2 = "[kworker/1:1]"
        // DNS query over SSL, used to resolve C2 server address
        $dns_query = "POST /dns-query HTTP/1.1\x0d\x0aHost:
dns.google\x0d\x0a"
        // iptables commands
        $iptables1 = "iptables -I %s -p tcp --dport %d -j ACCEPT
&>/dev/null"
        $iptables2 = "iptables -D %s -p tcp --dport %d -j ACCEPT
&>/dev/null"
        // Format strings used for system recon
        $sys_recon1 = "{\"ver\":\"%x\",\"mods\";["
        $sys_recon2 = "uptime: %lu mem_size: %lu mem_free: %lu"
        $sys_recon3 = "disk_size: %lu disk_free: %lu"
        $sys_recon4 = "hw: %02x:%02x:%02x:%02x:%02x:%02x"
        // Format string for filepath used to test access to device
filesystem
        $testpath = "%s/214688dsf46"
        // Format string for implant configuration filepath
        $confpath = "%s/rootfs_cfg"
        // Default file download path
        $downpath = "/var/tmp/a.tmp"

    condition:
        (uint32(0) == 0x464c457f) and (8 of them)
}

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_module_initialisation
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
rule CyclopsBlink_module_initialisation
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "Detects the code bytes used to initialise the
modules built into Cyclops Blink"
        date = "2022-02-23"
        hash1 = "3adf9a59743bc5d8399f67cab5eb2daf28b9b863"
        hash2 = "c59bc17659daca1b1ce65b6af077f86a648ad8a8"

    strings:
        // Module initialisation code bytes, simply returning the module
ID
        // to the caller
        $ = {94 21 FF F0 93 E1 00 08 7C 3F 0B 78 38 00 00 ?? 7C 03
             03 78 81 61 00 00 8E EB FF F8 7D 61 5B 78 4E 80 00 20}

    condition:
        (uint32(0) == 0x464c457f) and (any of them)
}

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_modified_install_upgrade
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_core_command_check
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
rule CyclopsBlink_core_command_check
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "Detects the code bytes used to test the command ID
being sent to the core component of Cyclops Blink"
        date = "2022-02-23"
        hash1 = "3adf9a59743bc5d8399f67cab5eb2daf28b9b863"
        hash2 = "c59bc17659daca1b1ce65b6af077f86a648ad8a8"

    strings:
        // Check for command ID equals 0x7, 0xa, 0xb, 0xc or 0xd
        $cmd_check = {81 3F 00 18 88 09 00 05 54 00 06 3E 2F 80 00
                      (07|0A|0B|0C|0D)}

    condition:
        (uint32(0) == 0x464c457f) and (#cmd_check == 5)
}

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_config_identifiers
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_handle_mod_0xf_command
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_default_config_values
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.

objects.name: CyclopsBlink_handle_mod_0x51_command
objects.description: YARA rule to detect related activity.
objects.pattern:
rule CyclopsBlink_handle_mod_0x51_command
{
    meta:
        author = "NCSC"
        description = "Detects the code bytes used to check commands sent
to module ID 0x51 and notable strings relating to the Cyclops Blink
update process"
        date = "2022-02-23"
        hash1 = "3adf9a59743bc5d8399f67cab5eb2daf28b9b863"
        hash2 = "c59bc17659daca1b1ce65b6af077f86a648ad8a8"

    strings:
        // Check for module command ID equals 0x1, 0x2 or 0x3
        $cmd_check = {88 1F [2] 54 00 06 3E 2F 80 00 (01|02|03)}
        // Legitimate WatchGuard filepaths relating to device
configuration
        $path1 = "/etc/wg/configd-hash.xml"
        $path2 = "/etc/wg/config.xml"
        // Mount arguments used to remount root filesystem as RW or RO
        $mnt_arg1 = "ext2"
        $mnt_arg2 = "errors=continue"
        $mnt_arg3 = {38 C0 0C 20}
        $mnt_arg4 = {38 C0 0C 21}

    condition:
        (uint32(0) == 0x464c457f) and (#cmd_check == 3) and
        ((@cmd_check[3] - @cmd_check[1]) < 0x200) and
        (all of ($path*)) and (all of ($mnt_arg*))
}

objects.name: T1059.004
objects.description: Cyclops Blink executes downloaded files using the Linux API function execlp.

objects.name: T1037.004
objects.description: Cyclops Blink is executed on device startup, using a modified S51armled RC script.

objects.name: T1542.001
objects.description: Cyclops Blink maintains persistence throughout the legitimate device firmware update process. This is achieved by patching the firmware when it is downloaded to the device.

objects.name: T1562.004
objects.description: Cyclops Blink modifies the Linux iptables firewall to enable C2 communication via a stored list of port numbers.

objects.name: T1036.005
objects.description: Cyclops Blink renames its running process to masquerade as a Linux kernel thread.

objects.name: T1082
objects.description: Cyclops Blink regularly queries device information.

objects.name: T1132.002
objects.description: Cyclops Blink command messages use a custom binary scheme to encode the specific command to be executed, as well as any command parameters required.

objects.name: T1008
objects.description: Cyclops Blink randomly selects a C2 server from contained lists of IPv4 addresses and port numbers.

objects.name: T1071.001
objects.description: Cyclops Blink can download files via HTTP or HTTPS.

objects.name: T1573.002
objects.description: Cyclops Blink C2 messages are individually encrypted using AES-256-CBC and sent underneath TLS. OpenSSL library functions are used to encrypt each message using a randomly generated key and IV, which are then encrypted using a hard-coded RSA public key.

objects.name: T1571
objects.description: Cyclops Blink contains a list of port numbers used for C2 communication. This list includes non-standard ports not typically associated with HTTP or HTTPS traffic.

objects.name: T1041
objects.description: Cyclops Blink is capable of uploading files to a C2 server.

objects.name: Analisi Malware: Cyclops Blink
objects.description: This report contains technical analysis and indicators associated with malware. cyclops blink.
